text: it has for me the hallmarks of great
works of art in that you want to see it
again and again and again and it evolves
as you spend more time with it and so
it's really for me a slice of real life
that eggleston brings to the camera you
can touch the fabric in this picture
it's just so real and again so rich in
color it's one of my favorites it's just
so evocative I think not just of the two
figures but the atmosphere of the room
that they're sitting in this could be a
scene from a movie couldn't it to depict
race and class it is the closest that
eggleston would ever come to looking at
race relations in the South absent any
other information you just have the
phenomenon of the black man standing
behind the white man in exactly the same
pose that makes that photographs are
wonderful what is it about this picture
both the boy pushing the shopping
trolleys back into the store what is it
that makes it stand out in what is just
such a routine seen that completely
bunnell completely ordinary moment you
get these extraordinary moments they
almost like surveillance but they're not
voyeuristic there's a feeling of
participating with those people in their
lives in the 1960s in Middle America
